The Biden administration could have restarted the deal the first day in office simply by lifting sanctions. I have no doubt that at that point Iran would have happily complied with the deal. The Biden administration is essentially taking the same position as the Trump administration and saying that the original deal was not good enough. They are using the concessions the Trump administration put in place as leverage to try to extract new concessions.  Basically I see the United States as an arrogant bully that is used to getting its way. There has never been any real evidence that Iran has a nuclear weapons program. The IAEA has debunked every accusation made by the US and Israel. During the Iran Iraq war Iraq was invading Iran and using chemical weapons against them. I ran had the ability to make chemical weapons in return but they didn't because it was against their religion to use weapons of mass destruction, even though the outcome of the war was not certain and their lives and families were at risk. If they weren't willing to create weapons of mass destruction then why would they now? If Iran does have a nuclear weapons program it is because the United States has pushed them into it. The benefit of this agreement is that it would help stop the United States and Israel from attacking Iran for no reason. (I recommend the book Manufactured Crisis.) Keep in mind that both Iran and the United States are signatories to the nuclear nonproliferation treaty. This means that the United States has a treaty with iran, ratified by Congress and therefore binding under the constitution, which says that Iran has the right to develop nuclear material as long as it does not reach weapons grade. This means that all of the enrichment that Iran has been doing they have a right to do under that treaty and the US is violating the terms of the treaty by trying to penalize them for it. It is understandable that Iran does not believe anything the United States says. At this point Iran is asking for assurances that the United States will stay in the agreement. The United States says they could not guarantee what the next president would do, which is absolutely correct because in a democracy the people have a right to vote in a new president who wants to go in a new direction. And I don't see Congress ratifying the agreement to bind it on the next president. So then Iran asked for assurances that at least the Biden administration will honor the agreement until the end of Biden's term. The US wouldn't even agree to that. Lifting sanctions is really worthless for Iran without those guarantees because companies will not enter and invest in Iran unless they know there can be some stability that they can be there for several years and conduct business without being forced to leave. I'm a little concerned about what all of this means. If the United States would have allowed the agreement to be renewed earlier it would have helped the prior more moderate Iranian president stay in power. Instead it looks to me as if the United States intentionally wanted the more hardline Iranian president to come to power because that would help Iran look more like a bad guy and would justify more aggressive action against them. It really looks to me as if the Biden administration wants to give the impression that they tried to make a deal but they really don't want a deal, they want Iran to look like the bad guy.

I believe the answer is highly likely to be no. Both sides have announced certain preconditions that seem to be mutually exclusive: Iran wants the initiative to come from the US by lifting all economic sanctions, and the latter calls for an immediate stop to uranium enrichment in Iran to lift the sanctions. Moreover, Iran currently experiences high tensions on its northern borders with Azerbaijan where it has multimillion Azeri population. Iran has deployed heavy military arsenal and warned that it would not tolerate any attack on its sovereignty. Making compromises in other international directions would undermine Raisi's domestic reputation as a hardline actor. The Biden administration has already mentioned more than once that they are ready to discuss JCPOA revival, but they have not received any substantive offers. They see their announcement of rejoining JCPOA as a main compromise to Iran. Taking into account the withdrawal from Afghanistan, the administration is unlikely to demonstrate much more detached position in this part of the Middle East. Even some European partners seem to be more flexible on this question, but their position had little effect on the US position. If you add to this equation Israel's hardened posture, everything becomes more puzzled. Recent developments in the US-Russia relations in terms of closing the Russian representation in NATO also demonstrates that the US currently is constrained in its eastern policies. I think when two states come from directly opposite political blocks with some turbulent political background, it is vital to lay a basis to recover the trust and willingness to understand each other's concerns. Once there is progress on this matter, anything else becomes technicality.

Regardless of the interest level of the Biden administration to rejoin JCPOA, Iran's continued enrichment of uranium, hardline statements from Iran's leadership, and the repeated delays in talks make it very unlikely that the U.S. even be able to rejoin the JCPOA. Not only has the Iranian Foreign Minister, Hossein Amir-Abdollahian, indicated JCPOA would not be a possibility during his tenure, the JCPOA is not a priority issue for the new president, Ebrahim Raisi. (https://foreignpolicy.com/2021/10/07/iran-deal-talks-jcpoa-vienna-nuclear-negotiations-raisi/#) Also, as Iran continues to enrich uranium, the JCPOA is simply loosing relevance as Iran moves past the terms set by the JCPOA. Iran is also reluctant to trust the U.S. again and is skeptical that the U.S. will lift the current sanctions. (https://foreignpolicy.com/2021/09/22/separate-nuclear-iran-deal-jcpoa-regional-security-saudi-arabia-uae/) Both parties have to want and need the deal. Iran does not want it and seems to be able to manage the effects from the economic sanctions to the point where it doesn't need the deal - especially within the next 2 1/2 months.

Iran Nukes the Case for a Biden Deal - The Wall Street Journal
https://www.wsj.com/articles/iran-nuclear-deal-biden-blinken-jcpoa-ebrahim-raisi-khamenei-11628539180
Tue, 10 Aug 2021 12:52:00 GMT
> But Supreme Leader Ali Khamenei has no intention of ending up like Mikhail Gorbachev. By ruthlessly engineering the election of a hard-liner’s hard-liner to the presidency, Mr. Khamenei has slammed the door on normalization and nailed it shut. 
> That’s only one of the problems afflicting the JCPOA. Instead of welcoming the Biden administration’s eagerness to return to President Obama’s Iran policy, Tehran has turned up its nose at American attempts to chart a course back to mutual compliance with the terms of the deal. The ease with which President Trump was able to dump the JCPOA, and the inability of outraged Europeans to contest his imposition of unilateral sanctions, created a healthy skepticism in Iran about the deal’s value. Tehran has realized that an executive agreement like the JCPOA has no legal force in the U.S. It is not simply that a future president could follow Mr. Trump’s footsteps and reject the nuclear deal. President Biden could sign the JCPOA one week and reimpose American sanctions on whatever grounds he chose the next, and Iran would have no recourse. 
> Rather than seeing American withdrawals from Afghanistan and Iraq as friendly gestures meriting a constructive response, the mullahs appear to have interpreted them as a sign that the Biden administration can be safely defied. Likely believing the White House is bent on Middle East withdrawal, no matter the cost, Tehran seems to have decided to double down on its confrontational approach to capitalize on perceived U.S. weakness. 
> A deepening confrontation with a radicalizing Iran is not what the Biden administration expected from its Middle East policy, but that is the reality with which it must cope. Attempting to placate Tehran through patience and restraint will likely only stoke the regime’s ambitions. The smell of blood in the water rarely inspires feelings of moderation and restraint among sharks. Note that negotiation is tricky, so without any particular insight into what each side is actually thinking, I don't really know how much to weigh think pieces like this one. The complexity of the US officially rejoining the JCPOA may be significant than I initially considered.  I had previously focused on the renegotiation between the US, Iran, and the four other signatories.  The contours of the rejoining the JCPOA matter. Congressional review appears like it will add 30-days. Given the negotiation complexity along with the potential process complexity, I am going to reduce my forecast materially to 16%. Thank you for your thoughtful response, @dowser. I agree with your premise that both sides continue to have incentives to come to agreement. My point was that Iran and Iranian leaders tend to have a much longer time horizon than do Western democracies with comparatively frequent and meaningful elections. The clerical Iranian leaders likely see no dissonance between this shocking breach of international law (in my earlier post about Iranian intelligence seeking to kidnap an American on U.S. soil) and their continued, slow, painful negotiations in Geneva. The current grouping of states seeking to subvert the post-World War II rules-based International Order (China, Russia, North Korea, Iran) all engage in these so-called “salami-slicing” tactics, to which I did not give adequate weight. I was previously well above the crowd (80%) and this event caused me to reevaluate my excessive optimism for a resolution within our question’s timeframe. I agree they very well may come to agreement, but I am just not as optimistic as I was that it would be in time for a “yes” on our question. In reference to your comparison, I do see important differences. In my view, one situation is a difference of tactics over confronting Russia’s potential economic coercion among long-standing treaty allies with myriad, deep shared political, economic, cultural, and strategic values and interests. The other situation is a multi-decade pariah nation posing a grave threat to international peace and security. The U.S. tends to allow wide latitude to its allies in many areas, much to the chagrin of elements of the American public. We have no view on the Canadian, British, or German public health insurance systems, for example, even though this serves as a significant competitive advantage for them in trade since their public pays for something that is a cost for U.S. firms. We did not force European allies to break diplomatic ties with Iran or Cuba, for example. Canadian executives running businesses in Cuba that were expropriated from U.S. citizens fear few, if any, repercussions. This is a much different situation than with respect to Iran, which has been an adversary for 42 years. In my view, it remains to be seen whether the clerics in Tehran believe they “need” to work with the U.S. or even agree that is possible to do so in way that guarantees their regime’s continued existence. I tend to think they are close watchers of U.S. politics and will be seeing what happens in the 2022 midterms. If the Dems get trounced and lose the House or Senate or both, then I think the mullahs will say, “what value is an agreement with one third of the U.S. Government, which may be gone in two more years, replaced someone who will snap back to 2017?”

This is a complex foreign policy problem for the Biden Administration, made more difficult by Israel.  The real questions here is how committed is Iran to the agreement and do they really have the ability/compacity to refine enough uranium for a nuclear bomb if they want to?  While Iran has a highly educated society and capable scientists, do the they have the resources and/or the real desire to have a nuclear bomb?  For example, despite being an oil rich country, energy prices in Iran are extremely high in comparison to other countries in the region.  This could make an argument for and against domestic nuclear energy.  On one hand the capital investment required to build a domestic nuclear reactor is in the billions (just look at the current nuclear power plant being built in Georgia, which is being delayed and at least a billion over budget).  On the other hand, once up and running, domestic nuclear energy is fairly cheap.  Bottom line, is domestic nuclear energy really the best course for Iran or do they really desire to have at least the ability to build a nuclear bomb?  It would seem to be the latter.  The Biden Administration clearly wants to rejoin the agreement, but with concessions, which Iran does not appear to be inclined to agree to.  What is the breaking point for the Biden Administration?  Iran?  A lot more information is needed in order to attempt to make an accurate prediction.  Any suggested additional information is always greatly appreciated.  Additionally, the formation of the new Israeli government will have an impact on if the U.S. officially rejoins the JCPOA.  If Netanyahu continues to be prime minster the odds would probably decline at least slightly.

But many of the possible paths may involve the verification of Iran's uranium enrichment, etc., which keeps on progressing - out of step with diplomacy: A) If U.S. does lift sanctions to Iran's liking, Iran would have to stop its enrichment and/or rejoin the JCPOA as they purportedly say they would. I think the current crowd forecast is a little high because of some complications: 1. a.	The enrichment of uranium is being justified by Iran under a new law which requires 120kg of uranium to be enriched to 20% annually (purportedly for peaceful purposes). This could take some months for Iran to accomplish. Even before the uranium enrichment began at the Fordow facility, Iran’s stockpile of uranium was reported to be about 12 times the allowed limit, according to the IAEA (https://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-54912402). So it’s possible it could take quite some time for Iran to re-enter compliance, even after it ceases to enrich uranium to 20%. 
2.The deal includes European nations as well, and NATO has just expanded its presence and mission in Iraq (https://www.npr.org/2021/02/19/969351655/nato-announces-plan-to-increase-presence-in-iraq). Iran may be less likely to want to negotiate with increased Western military activity in its backyard. The threat from Israel is also something to consider, with the assassination of a top Iranian scientist by the Mossad in November. 
3. The recent rocket attack on a U.S. military base (https://www.nbcnews.com/news/military/iranian-backed-militias-likely-behind-deadly-rocket-attack-u-s-n1258380) as well as the planned exclusion of U.N. inspectors from Iranian nuclear facilities (https://apnews.com/article/iran-parlianment-bill-nuclear-inspection-e2f2225c1f91c5c09afaf776cf9e04e3) will put pressure on Biden to be tough on Iran, refuse to remove sanctions and possibly even add more.
4. There has been some pressure from US allies (Germany, France, UK) to renegotiate the deal to address the Iranian rocket program  (https://www.dw.com/en/biden-and-iran-back-to-the-old-nuclear-deal-or-negotiate-a-new-one/a-55983851) and support for non-state actors (as demonstrated by the rocket attack by Iranian-backed militia in Iraq). Both the US and Iran want this to happen. I am assuming that this question resolves as yes even if the agreement gets modified. It's important to understand that Iran is still in compliance with the agreement and always has been. The JCPOA states that if the US ever leaves the agreement then some of the restrictions on Iran lift. So Iran can enrich uranium to the level that they are currently and is still in compliance with the agreement because of the fact that the United States left the agreement. But now the United States is trying to use the sanctions put in place by the Trump administration as a lever to get additional concessions out of Iran. I believe this is not in good faith, especially considering the fact that this is the exact same negotiation team that originally set up the agreement in the first place. As additional context, keep in mind that both Iran and the United States are signatories to the nuclear non-proliferation treaty. This is a treaty that has been ratified by the US Congress, so it is binding under the US Constitution. The non-proliferation treaty states that Iran has the right to produce civilian grade nuclear material (which is understood to mean up to about 90% enrichment) . This means that the United States has agreed by a treaty binding under the US Constitution that Iran has the right to enrich material up to 90%. So it is arguably a treaty violation for the United States to put sanctions on Iran for enriching only up to 20%. whenever Iran goes to the negotiation table they always say they have a right to do this, and they are absolutely correct because the United States has agreed they have the right to do this. Not only that, but the non-proliferation treaty states that more developed nations like the United States have an obligation to assist developing nations like Iran in developing their program.  I'll also point out that it doesn't matter if they produce more civilian-grade material than they could possibly use in their reactor, because it is a product that can be sold internationally. Even the United States has purchased heavy water from Iran. Accusing Iran of wanting to develop a nuclear weapon just because they are producing more material than they could possibly use, is like accusing the United States of wanting to destroy the environment because they cut down more trees than they use every year. It is an exportable product, and Iran has the right to produce it under treaty. if you go through the last several decades the United States has consistently acted in bad faith with Iran. Us politics in the Middle East is very simple: the United States does whatever Saudi Arabia and Israel want it to do. However, the Biden administrations exit from the Yemen conflict leads me to think that the Biden administration is willing to ignore what Saudi Arabia wants to a certain extent. Ultimately I think both the United States and Iran want this to happen. It's just a matter of weather something stupid happens along the way to sabotage the situation.
